posts.name: ScottRandallWay
posts.cooked: I noticed that placing a thread wait within a command results in an exception due to causing an interruption. For my command, which involves waiting one second after the `isFinished` condition is met, I implemented a workaround by introducing a local integer variable. This variable increments each time `isFinished` is triggered, and when it reaches 50 (assuming each iteration takes approximately 20ms), `isFinished` returns true. However, I'm seeking feedback on whether this approach is reasonable or if there's a more effective method.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: To do this in the command-based framework, you'd probably want to make a sequential command group. The first item in the sequence would be your existing command, then a wait command, and then the command to turn off the motor.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: In general we recommend building commands with factories and composition rather than subclassing.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked: The isFinished function runs every 20ms, and I used a local integer variable to track iterations. I incremented the counter when isFinished returned true and checked against a threshold of 50 iterations to reach 1 second. However, this approach isn’t reliable for precise time counting in FRC systems. WPILib’s Timer class provides a more accurate way to measure elapsed time, avoiding issues related to iteration timing.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
The assistant has provided an example of how to respond when the user's query includes specific formatting or additional instructions. I need to analyze the user's request carefully. First, they want me to clean up some text by removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements while preserving the original meaning. Looking at their example: Their input had a paragraph containing an HTML link within a `

` tag, along with specific styling attributes in a comment. In the response, they removed both the `

` tag and the inline styles from the comment, leaving only the URL without any extra information. So, for this task, I should follow these steps: 1. Identify and remove all HTML tags from the given text. 2. Eliminate any unnecessary elements that don't contribute to the core message. 3. Ensure that the cleaned-up text maintains proper English grammar and punctuation. 4. Preserve the original meaning without altering it excessively. 5. Output a single, well-formatted paragraph without any line breaks or additional explanations. Now, let's process the given text accordingly. The given text contains a paragraph with a hyperlink embedded within it via an `` tag. Additionally, there are inline style attributes (`class` and `rel`) in the comment above the link, which are not necessary for conveying the intended information. To clean this up effectively: - Remove the `

` tag since it wraps the content unnecessarily. - Extract and remove the inline style attributes from the comment to eliminate extraneous information. - Retain only the essential part of the link—specifically, the URL—which serves as the primary purpose of the text. Following these steps ensures that the resulting text is concise, grammatically correct, and focused on its intended purpose. posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked: I think both options are valid. There are pros and cons to each approach. With subclassing, using the Timer is the correct choice. There are also subtle differences in timing between chaining a wait command and handling the timer internally that might be important.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: subtle differences between the two implementations may not significantly affect their functionality or compatibility. Given that one uses a Timer internally, the minor distinctions likely do not cause substantial issues. Prioritizing broader problem-solving and system improvement could yield more impactful results than focusing excessively on trivial differences.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: If you don’t code the use of the Timer class correctly, then it won’t work right. If you code the use of the Timer class exactly as the WaitCommand does, then obviously it will work but why duplicate what others have already coded for you? And it is best as others point out above to use the Wait factory that I linked to. Reduced amount of code is concise, faster to code, easier to read and understand - less prone to errors for all involved. Use of the factories and composites emphasize the Robot action problem being solved instead of being concerned with how the solution was coded in the programming language. That is the Command factories and compositions are the language of your problem instead of using more code to show how to accomplish a solution in Java, C++, etc. I believe Oblarg has referred to this “as working in the problem state instead of the solution state.” The fun part for most roboticists is making the robot move to our command and it’s generally a bit tedious and error prone to have to worry about how exactly to accomplish that with basic Java statements with your own design of state machines, etc. Command Based is the customized language of robot action – basic Java is not and factories and compositions are your friends to ease Command Based coding.

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked:
The primary difference is when and how the timer is initiated. In a sequential command group, if the current command finishes, the next one is initialized in the same loop. For the wait command, that means it’s restarted and you’re golden. For example, performing some tasks followed by starting a timer with your `isFinished` method returning `$timer.hasElapsed` produces the same result as sequentially executing that work and then using a wait command. If additional steps are involved, you have more control over timer setup, start, restart, or reset timing.

One subtle consideration from my initial thought process is that if both your work and timer begin during `initialize` in a custom command, they will start simultaneously. However, if the first command (e.g., moving a motor) is an instant command, it runs during sequential initialization. When `execute` is called, it does nothing, `isFinished` returns true, and the initialize method triggers on your wait command. This causes your wait command to begin approximately 20 milliseconds later compared to if they were part of the same subclassed command. While this may seem small, it’s worth noting due to potential timing implications.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
One thing that hasn’t been pointed out is that that’s not a great way to do time counting in pseudo real time systems like what we’re doing in FRC. 
The reason why is because that 20 ms timing might be inaccurate due to a lot of reasons. Like. A lot a lot. Most of them end up skewing your code to i…
